meanings.definition: To strip off the skin or outer covering of something.
meanings.sent1: The chef will flay the potato before cooking it.
meanings.sent2: The hunter needed to flay the deer after the successful hunt.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally flayed the banana while trying to peel it.
meanings.sent4: The storm's strong winds seemed to flay the trees of their leaves.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brushstrokes seemed to flay the canvas, revealing its true colors.

meanings.sent1: The teacher will flay the student for not completing the homework.
meanings.sent2: The boss decided to flay the employee for the repeated mistakes.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to flay the mouse for its mischief.
meanings.sent4: Her words had the power to flay his self-esteem.
meanings.sent5: The judge's harsh tone seemed to flay the defendant's excuses.

meanings.definition: To whip or beat someone harshly.
meanings.sent1: The cruel master would flay the slaves for any disobedience.
meanings.sent2: The villain planned to flay the hero in front of the crowd.
meanings.sent3: The wind seemed to flay the flag against the pole.
meanings.sent4: The boxer's punches seemed to flay his opponent with each hit.
meanings.sent5: The waves crashed against the shore, appearing to flay the rocks.
